column1: Pentazocine is a medicine used to treat moderate to severe pain.
In most opioid poisonings, the person will have signs of opioid intoxication.

Symptoms may include: - Bluish skin color (cyanosis) - Breathing difficulty - Constipation - Dizziness - Drowsiness - Dry mouth - Headache - Rapid heartbeat and blood pressure changes - Pinpoint pupils - Seizures - Stomach cramps - Vomiting Pentazocine is a weak opioid.

The person may receive: - Activated charcoal - Airway support, including oxygen, breathing tube through the mouth (intubation), and breathing machine (ventilator) - Blood and urine tests - Chest x-ray - EKG (electrocardiogram, or heart tracing) - Fluids through a vein (intravenous or IV) - Laxative - Medicines to treat symptoms, including naloxone (Narcan), an antidote to help reverse the effect of the poison, multiple doses may be needed
Pentazocine overdose is usually much less serious than other opioid medicine overdoses, such as heroin and morphine.
Rarely do antidotes, such as Narcan, need to be used.
